abstract.p: Virial stress measures in atomistic models obtained by appropriate spatial and temporal averaging are known to be representations of continuum stresses in bulk materials. Using molecular dynamics simulations, this effort shows that some local and dynamic features of the continuum stress exist in the dynamic response of the virial stress. The spatially averaged but temporally fluctuating behaviour of the hydrostatic component of the virial stress is observed in both time and frequency domains at a mean stress-free state for a nanostructure at a target temperature. An atomistic-scale model with one finite dimension and two infinite dimensions was utilized to represent a thin single crystal film. Numerical simulations were performed with force fields and lattice parameters corresponding to gold. The initial temperature, pressure, and volume states for the material were determined using two equilibrium procedures that produced convergent energy and stress states. The dynamics of the virial stresses in atomistic ensembles show several dynamic and local characteristics of the continuum stresses.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Studies at the nanoscale with atomistic representations of materials are increasingly used to determine the mechanical behaviour of nanostructures [1–9]. Analysis of fracture in materials using atomistic models can also be found in the literature [10–13]. Definition of stress measures from the energy, force, and velocities of discrete atoms is critical for correlating the behaviour of atomistic ensembles with that of the bulk material. Virial stress measures are often used to represent continuum stresses in atomistic ensembles and such a correlation has seen some controversy in the recent times. Other stress measures in atomistic ensembles also exist as representations of the continuum stress. Basinski et al. [14] based their calculations on a volumetric partition of the bulk homogenous stress tensor. They postulated that the bulk stress tensor continues to characterize the stress state in a small volume about an atom even in the inhomogeneous atomic ensembles. Hardy and Karo [15] used a finite-valued and finite-ranged localization function to define stress about an atom. This stress measurement theoretically remains invariant with the choice of range and volume of influence when a proper localization function is selected. Zimmerman et al. [16] compared Hardy’s expression for stress and local volume averages of the virial stress within a face-centred cubic (FCC) crystal. Their analysis showed that both virial stress and Hardy’s definitions converge when properly averaged over time and over large numbers of atoms. Zhou [17] argued that virial stress as defined with both potential and kinetic terms is not equivalent to the Cauchy stress. Shen and Atluri [18] and Sun et al. [19] supported this view. However, Subramaniyan and Sun [20] showed that virial stress is equivalent to Cauchy stress when properly averaged over space and time domains by providing comparisons with thermal expansion coefficients and continuum thermal stresses induced under various boundary conditions. Use of both spatial averaging over large (or entire ensembles) and temporal averaging (long periods of time) is seen as a key for virial stress measures to suitably represent continuum states of the bulk.

In this effort, one examines the characteristics of the temporal variations in virial stress in both time and frequency domains. Further, a finite sized crack is introduced in the atomistic ensemble and the nature of the virial stress measures when averaged over the entire structure examined. The objective of this effort is to determine if the dynamic characteristics of the virial stress states in the atomic ensemble retain features of the natural modes of vibration and wave propagation characteristics of the bulk continuum. A robust correlation between the wave propagation characteristics in the frequency domain and the bulk structural response enables a mechanism for predicting the effective macroscopic (continuum) properties such as the elastic moduli of complex heterogeneous nanostructures. The rest of this article describes the details of the simulations and the observations made. This article mainly focuses on the hydrostatic component of the virial stress (pressure), and individual components of the stress tensor are not presented in detail. The dynamic response of the stress state is studied with no applied excitation loading and therefore must correspond to the free vibration characteristics of a structure about a mean stress-free state.

sec.title: 2.1 Configurations
sec.p:
Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with embedded atom method (EAM) potential are carried out on a single crystal gold ensemble. Figure 1 shows the reference axes and the dimensions of the model used. The atoms in this model are arranged in a 4.08 Å FCC lattice. The model x-, y-, and z-axes are oriented along the [1 0 0], [0 1 0], and [0 0 1] crystalline directions, respectively. Three thickness sizes, 244.8, 163.2, and 81.6 Å, are considered and the representative volume elements had 20 × 60 × 20 cells, 20 × 40 × 20, and 20 × 20 × 20 cells, respectively The 20 × 40 × 20 cell domain had the dimensions 81.6 × 163.2 × 81.6 Å3 and had 64 800 atoms in the simulation domain. One assumes that the model is periodic about the simulation box faces with normals along ±x and ±z and that it has finite boundaries at faces with ±y normals. The molecules do not interact across the ±y boundaries. MD simulations are performed using LAMMPS MD package [21]. Fig. 1
Representative volume element and orientation of reference axes

sec.title: 2.2 Interatomic potential and the virial stress measure
sec.p: The EAM is considered as the inter-atomic force potential [22, 23]. EAM potential consists of a many body terms representing the interaction of an embedding atom core with the electronic charge density of the remaining atoms in the system and a pair-wise term representing the electrostatic interactions between the atoms cores. The total energy E of a system of N atoms can be written as follows (1) where φij is the pair potential function between atoms i and j and rij the distance between atom i and j. Fi, the embedding term, is the quantum mechanical energy involving the influence of electron density. This term represents the energy required to embed an atom into an electron gas with a density ρ¯i, which is defined as follows (2) where ρj represents the energy contribution from each neighbouring jth atom. For a system of atoms in equilibrium state, the force from embedding term balances the force from the pair-wise interaction term. Equation (3) defines the atomic electron density required by the EAM potential [24]. βM in this equation is an adjustable parameter (3)
Equation (4) defines the pair-wise interaction with a Morse pair potential (4)

DM, RM, and αM in equation (4) are the depth of the potential, the distance to the minimum, and a measure of the curvature at the minimum, respectively. The cutoff distance rcut is the defined as the distance at which functions φ(r), ρ (r), and their derivatives are forced to vanish smoothly. For metallic gold, the parameters for Morse pair potential are rcut (Å) = 5.5155, βM (1/Å) = 3.6967, αM (1/Å) = 1.8964, DM (eV) = 0.6748, and RM (Å) = 2.5686. Equation (5) defines the virial stress as the averaged measure of the interatomic force interactions of atoms with their neighbours [13] (5)

In this equation, NR is the number of atoms in the region, mα the mass, viα the ith component of the velocity of atom α, fiαβ the ith component of force between atoms α and β, and rjαβ the jth component of centre distance between atoms α and β. Equation (5) represents an averaged atomic stresses for the volume of the periodic box. Here, the first term is associated with the contribution from kinetic energy caused by thermal vibration and the second term the potential energy because of applied deformations.

sec.title: 3 MEAN STRESS-FREE STATE AT A DESIRED TEMPERATURE
sec.p: A zero-mean (stress-free) state is chosen as the known continuum stress state for the bulk material at a constant temperature of 250 K. The temperature of the ensemble was raised from its initial state at 0 to 250 K using two different heating procedures. The choice of the target temperature of 250 K is arbitrary and the methodologies can be applied to any other temperature of interest. The system has been equilibrated at 0 K for 50 ps.

In the first heating procedure, the single crystal gold ensemble is heated from 0 up to 250 K in increments of 50 K under NVT conditions in which the number of atoms in the model (N), the volume (V), and the temperature (T) are controlled. Each 50 K rise in temperature was achieved over a time of 600 ps with time increments of 0.01 ps. The ensemble was equilibrated after each temperature rise step for 800 ps (a dwell step) under NVT conditions with constant temperature. Figure 2(a) depicts the heating and dwelling sequence which was repeated for every 50 K rise in temperature until the system reaches the desired final equilibrium temperature of 250 K. One further equilibrates the system by applying a barostat set at 0.0001 bar and the temperature held at 250 K for an additional 3000 ps. One considers the resultant system as representative of the bulk material with a stress-free state at 250 K. The temporal variations of the mean hydrostatic stress (1/3σkk) was obtained from the virial stresses after averaging spatially over the last 3000 ps of the simulation time and was found to be zero (with variations of −40 and 40 MPa). The temperature of the ensemble was raised, the pressure barostat applied over 7000 ps (700 000 time steps), and the system over an additional 3000 ps (300 000 steps) equilibrated for a total of 10 ns (1 000 000 time steps). Fig. 2
Determination of initial state for the ensemble at 250°K. Process (a): Temperature rise under NVT conditions followed by pressure control with NPT (upper time axis). Process (b): Sequential temperature (NVT) and pressure (NPT) control after every 600 ps and 50 K temperature rise (lower time axis)

As an alternative process, the effects of sequentially heating under NVT conditions and setting the barostat under NPT conditions after each 50 K temperature rise were examined, as shown in Fig. 2(b). This heating at NVT and equilibration at NPT cycle were repeated until the system reaches a temperature of 250 K. Both these procedures resulted in the same total energy at the target temperature of 250 K. The mean pressure was again found to be zero after averaging both spatially and temporally.

Next, the kinetic and potential components of the pressure component of the virial stress are examined. Figure 3 shows that the mean value of kinetic component of the stress changes with the temperature. The large fluctuations of potential component of the pressure observed during heating steps die down after the subsequent NPT equilibrium steps. The mean equilibrium value of the potential component for this example is found to be about 200 MPa, as shown in Fig. 3, which is equal but opposite in sign to the mean equilibrium value of the KE component. This results in a zero mean pressure when both these components are considered. Using only the PE component to represent the stress state in the ensemble will result in a finite offset in the pressure computation. Fig. 3
(a) Kinetic component, (b) potential component and (c) virial stress

The time domain responses of the hydrostatic pressure computed from virial stress at the beginning of the final NPT equilibrium step (simulation time range of 6200–6300 ps) and at its end (9900–10 000) are shown in Fig. 4(a) and (b), respectively. The figure shows stable and periodic time domain variation of the pressure with high-frequency and low-frequency components. This motivates the analysis in the frequency domain and determination of the dominant frequency modes. Fig. 4
Time domain response of pressure at the (a) beginning and (b) end of the final equilibrium step

The dynamic response of pressure was analysed in the frequency domain using fast Fourier transform. The chosen time step of 0.01 ps for the MD simulations corresponds to a sampling rate of 100 THz and produces a frequency bandwidth of 50 THz at a frequency resolution of 1 GHz.

sec.title: 4 SPECTRAL ANALYSIS OF PRESSURE STATES
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the frequency spectrum of the hydrostatic stress (pressure) components for three thickness values 244.8, 163.2, and 81.6 Å of the thin gold lattice model. Data are taken over 3000 ps (300 000 time steps) after the temperature rise and pressure barostat steps. Fig. 5
Structural and lattice scale vibration response of the hydrostatic stress for three domain thickness values: (a) 81.6 × 244.8 × 81.6 Å3, (b) 81.6 × 163.2 × 81.6 Å3 and (c) 81.6 × 81.6 × 81.6 Å3

In this effort, the thickness vibration modes for plane wave propagation in an infinitely thin film are focused. Assuming that the thickness of the film is 2b and the plate is infinitely long and wide, the frequencies of the three lowest vibration modes are given in equation (6) [25] when n = 1 (6)

The material stiffness constants C66 (shear modulus), C′2, and C′3 can be written in terms of the bulk elastic properties. Assuming isotropic behaviour of the bulk gold with modulus (E) of 78 GPa and Poisson’s ratio (ν) of 0.42, the stiffness coefficients are given as (7)

The three thickness vibration modes for a 244.8 Å thick film are 24.3, 65.6, 24.3 GHz (since C44 = C66 = C′3) and for the 163.2 Å thickness film are 36.5, 98.41, and 36.5 GHz. Therefore, one identifies a frequency range of interest between 10 and 100 GHz in which one expects structural vibration modes in the virial stress measures obtained from MD methods. Figure 5 shows the frequency response of pressure for three different thickness values at 250 K for a zero-mean stress state. Figure 5(a) shows the dominant frequencies for the model with the 244.8 Å thickness (60 cells in the thickness direction). Figure 5(b) and (c) shows the response spectrum for the model with thickness values 163.2 Å (40 cells) and 81.6 Å (20 cells), respectively. For the 244.8 Å thickness model, the lowest dominant mode observed in the frequency spectra of pressure component of virial stress is at 29 GHz, which is close to the frequency of thickness mode shear vibrations (24.3 GHz) predicted by equation (6). The model with 163.2 Å thickness has the lowest mode at 43 GHz and that for 81.6 Å is at 87 GHz. This is a single dominant peak in the frequency range for the structural modes that correlate well with the expected stiffness changes and the increase in lowest fundamental mode, as given in equation (6). There is a difference in the quantitative predictions from the MD simulation to that from the thin film vibration model. The analytical model assumes that the film is infinite and that the wave propagation is limited to thickness direction only. The MD simulations are conducted with finite sized representative volume with periodic boundary conditions on the ±X and ±Z faces. The wave propagation is not strictly thickness mode in the MD simulations. However, the lowest structural mode can be robustly identified in the temporal variations of the pressure computed from the viral stresses. Bulk vibration in the thickness direction has not been observed in the atomistic snapshots.

Several higher frequency modes observed in the 100 GHz to 10 THz are various phonon and lattice vibration modes. The highest frequency (6.6 THz) corresponds to the lowest length scale, which is the lattice spacing of 4.08 Å. The three models shown here have different thickness values but the same lattice spacing of 4.08 Å. The spectral response of pressure shows identical behaviour at the high frequencies with 6.6 THz being the most dominant mode in the high-frequency range for all three models.

Figure 6 shows the frequency spectra for normal stress components, σxx, σyy, and σzz, computed from virial stress measures for the model with 163.2 Å thickness. The dominant frequencies are present only in the σyy component. The other two normal stress components are σxx, and σzz and have only high-frequency components and no dominant modes in the frequency range corresponding to structural modes. Fig. 6
Spectral response of normal stress components for the model with 163.2 Å thickness (Sxx = σxx; Syy = σyy; and Szz = σzz)

Next, a discrete crack of finite length at the centre of the 163.2 Å model was created by removing pair-wise interactions between atoms on both sides of the crack plane. After the crack initiation, the model was equilibrated for another 10 000 ps under NPT conditions. One simulation with a crack length of 32.64 Å and another with crack length 65.28 Å were performed. Figure 7 shows the total energies of the system with 32.64 and 65.28 Å crack lengths. The difference in the energy level is attributable to the presence of crack surfaces and proportional to the area of new surfaces introduced into the model. Figure 8 shows the frequency response of the last 3000 ps of the hydrostatic stresses with 32.64 and 65.28 Å crack lengths. The lowest dominant mode shifts from 43 GHz in the uncracked configuration to 40 GHz for the model with 32.64 Å crack. This decrease in the frequency indicates reduced stiffness of the structure caused by introduction of the crack in the model. Increasing the size of the crack to 65.28 Å further reduces the frequency of the fundamental mode. The model with 65.38 Å crack has the lowest fundamental frequency at 32 GHz. Fig. 7
Total energy response during the heating and pressure equilibrium steps. Crack faces are created at 10 000 ps
Fig. 8
Spectral response of pressure 32.64 and 65.28 Å cracks in the model with thickness 163.2 Å

sec.title: 5 CONCLUDING REMARKS
sec.p: In this effort, the dynamics of the virial stresses of a single crystal atomistic ensemble at a mean zero stress state and at an arbitrary temperature is investigated. The purpose of this study is to determine if any useful information exists in the temporal and local variations of virial stress measures that can be correlated to the structural dynamics of the bulk material.

Virial stress measures not only represent the mean continuum stress state after spatial and temporal averging but several characteristics of the dynamics of the stress state can also be recovered from its temporal variations. Pressure computed from stress virial shows the expected dominant modes in the frequency range where structural modes are expected. Also, one observes that the dominant mode predicted by the thin film continuum model can be recovered from the MD simulations results. As is the case with the continuum analysis, this mode is present only in the σyy component of the virial stress. One can also distinguish the dominant low-frequency mode to be thickness vibration of the plate. The resonance frequency in the structural vibration range (10–100 GHz) for the thicker structure is lower than that of the thinner structures. While the bending mode stiffness of plate will increase with thickness, the thickness vibration modes will decrease (equation (6)). The presence of this mode is expected theoretically in this problem and is observed in the frequency response of the stresses computed with MD.

The high-frequency response (1–10 THz) depends on the nature of the lattice vibrations. As all three models have the same lattice structure and interatomic force interactions, the high-frequency reponse is identical for the three models. One notes, with interest, that the dominant modes in the intermediate frequency range (100 GHz to 1 THz) differ for the three models, indicating diversity in the phonon dispersion in the model. The insertion of discrete crack planes in the model leads to lowering of the dominant structural mode. The influence of the crack size is also evident.
